DOC.HEAD: Albanian News Agency Reports on Romanian Uprising
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Albania's state news agency on Saturday issued an unusually frank report on the Romanian revolt against dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, whose regime had much in common with the Albanian leadership. With the ouster of Ceausescu, Albania remains the last stalwart of Stalinism in Eastern Europe. But ATA's reporting indicated the present Tirana leadership was at least not opposed to Ceausescu's reported ouster. Romania was the last member of the Soviet alliance to be hit with the wave of reform. Earlier this year, Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria, East Germany and Czechoslovakia each embraced liberal change. The other two Eastern European nations, Albania and Yugoslavia, are non-aligned nations. Yugoslavia broke with Moscow in 1948 because its founder, the late Jozip Broz Tito, espoused a less harsh brand of Communism than Stalin. Albania broke with the Kremlin in 1961 to continue its orthodox Stalinist course. Long-time leader Enver Hoxha led his country into increasing isolation, and the nation of 3 million became one of the most closed societies in the world. Under Ramiz Alia, who took over after Hoxha's death in 1985, the country renewed diplomatic relations with dozens of countries and opened up somewhat to tourism, but Alia has continued to abhor the reforms in the Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries. The ATA report quoted Western and Soviet bloc news agencies in its dispatch and noted that the Soviet news agency Tass had been unusually vivid in its reporting of the Romanian situation. The dispatch could indicate a further opening in the poorest nation in Europe. The news agency has not issued any editorial comment on the situation in Romania. ATA has on previous occasions quoted Western and other foreign news agencies but usually only in connection with the situation in neighboring Yugoslavia, where there is a large ethnic Albanian population.
